content:
r 23, 2012
												The whole game takes place on Halloween night where you must rescue your twin brother (or sister, depending on who you choose) who has been kidnapped by candy-stealing monsters. You have to trick-or-treat at every lighted house to unlock other areas in the game world. If a monster opens a door you will engage in a random turn-based battle where your costume powers will come in handy. On your quest you will meet other trick-or-treaters and pick up more followers for your search party. Collect candy from trash bags and smashed pumpkins which can be used to purchase perks in monster battles. Complete mini-quests to earn experience so you can level up. Do classic Halloween activities, like bob for apples and compete in a costume contest. Collect Creepy Treat trading cards and materials to unlock more costumes that have special abilities.It's a unique blend of rpg-ing and casual gameplay that perfectly captures the spirit of Halloween. A must-have for those too old to trick-or-treat.

er 27, 2011
												Costume Quest is an amusing, anime style, adventure game with some unique dynamics. Firstly, costumes you pick up become useful in the game world in two ways. One, they each have a unique ability, like the robot costume to boost your speed and let you jump off ramps, and secondly, they become genuine fighting equipment, changing your character into what the costume represents. Be it a knight, or a fancy big robot, the costumes have incredibly power in this fun and quirky game by the creators of Psychonauts. Definelty a fun little game to play, and a get a fresh taste of Double Fine on PC.

content:
er 29, 2013
												This one was a surprise. When looking at some pictures, I wasn't expecting much, but was surprised by it. This game has what you can expect from Double Fine, very funny and well written dialogue, fun combat system and a nice world to explore. The biggest flaw of this game, is it's length and scope. It's a short game. But the 6-8 hours it will take you to complete it, will be fully enjoyed. The story, although quite simplistic, is fun and entertaining. The combat system is  very nice, it's a JRPG turn based system with some quick time events thrown in between. When you enter battle, you'll transform into the costume you're wearing, so if you're using a cardboard robot costume, in battle you turn into a full laser shooting robot. The game has a lot of costumes and all of them very different from each other so you'll have to consider what costumes are best for each character and each situation. To add even more diversity, you have battle stamps to collect and use. These give some additional passive abilities, and make a lot of difference in combat. The game has a very simple level system and currency (candy). You can use candy to buy some upgrades and stamps to further develop your character. All in all, this is a very good bur short RPG, and I recommend it to everyone who likes the genre.

er 1, 2013
												Simply a short cute little game.  The art style is great, the story and characters are fun and the unlockables are simple enough to collect but still rewarding to find.  The game is not without its shortcomings though, the fights really started to feel repetitive around half way though the game and by the end I was starting to dread the idea of another fight sequence.  However, because the game is short (~5 to 7 hours) and fighting is not a huge part of the game, this is not the huge drawback it would be for a longer more serious game.In the end I plan on making this game a halloween tradition, it is cute and fun, and I would recommend this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
er 27, 2013
												Costume Quest is one of those unusual games you either love or hate. It is quite original, as is the trademark of Tim Schafer and the great Double Fine Productions, and offers a mixture of RPG and Adventure quite unseen in all the role-playing games I have played so far. A possible problem is that it merely brushes the surface of the genre and never goes in-depth. Don't expect neat level up and careful customization of your party, Costume Quest need to be played for the taste of its storyline, full of humor and for the cool gust it blows on a game market filled with clones. I also continued to play this game for its atmosphere, despite the repetition and the boredom that may occur after the too many similar moments of gameplay: the combat system barely evolves throughout the (short) story and the items hunts sometimes break the rhythm.To conclude, I would recommend it only to those who are ok with playing a game for its particular taste and the polish of its storyline rather than for the mechanics of its gameplay. Once again, Costume Quest is a very short game (I maxed it out in less than seven hours) but it is definitely a great pick for those who are looking for a bit share of originality .

												I don't want to hate on this game. I love the story. I love the characters. I love the dialogue. I love the art style.I hate grindy JRPG combat.Where 75% of your game time is spent in combat, it should be engaging; not a throwback to the NES era. After my fourth fight, I found myself avoiding enemies whenever possible. Not because of the difficulty, but because each fight is another 2-3 minute delay from that quest item that I was looking for in the game world. I challenge anyone to convince me that this style of combat makes the game fun.If there were a quarter as many enemies, and you used puzzle-solving to overcome them, this game would gel a lot better.

												Costume Quest is the journey of a few kids to find as much candy as they can on Halloween (and maybe save one of their sisters along the way... if they feel like it). It's innocent fun that conjures up feelings of nostalgia that I'm sure we can all relate to, while positively radiating with a pristine aura of charm and joy. Now if all that doesn't already sound appealing to you, there are also a ton of innuendos and jokes that only adults can connect with strewn throughout.This journey should take you around 5 hours to complete, even if you seek to obtain every single collectable. It's definitely pretty brief in terms of longevity, but I still really enjoyed my experience.If you're willing to let the kid inside of you out for a bit of fun, I'd say this game is worth at least one playthrough.

number of helpful: 6 of 14 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 27, 2014
												I like the idea for costume quest. The visional style fits very well with the game. The game has some fun characters too.What I don't like with the game is that it is extremely repetitive. The first area you are in was pretty fun. But it feels like the game might as well has ended there. Because you then get to another area where you have basically the same quests again, just at a different location. The quests aren't very fun either. The combat is very repetitive because only have one normal attack and a special attack that you get after two attacks. So every fight is: regular attack which follows with a quick time event to get the maximum damage out of your attack, do this for every character. Then quick time event to reduce damage from the enemy. Then repeat this to get special attack, do special attack. if the enemy isn't dead do it again. The concept for the game is very good. It could have been an awesome game. But sadly it's too repetitive and it kind of falls flat. Even though the game is very short is feels far to long for what the actual content of the game. It feels like they made the game longer by just using the same quest again with a new background texture.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 7, 2014
												I usually try to stay away from stuff that is cute and kidsy, but this game is actually not really like that. It is a charming little game with really great graphic design and a good turn based rpg combat system like Final Fantasy style. You go around a town map doing quests and it is so far a lot of fun. Double Fine ♥♥♥♥ed up Iron Brigade bad which was really unfortunate, but they have a gem on their hands here with this game. The huge flaws in this game though is that it is very short (I beat the main game + the dlc in 7 hours), there is no replay value: once you beat it there is no reason to ever play it again, and it could also be more difficult. One of my favorite short playthroughs that I have played in a long time. I don't know why exactly but it just strikes a chord with me and I love it. I think because it reminds me of one of my favorite games of all time, Earthbound on the Super Nintendo. A very good game, just way too short. Catch it on sale and only on sale.

												It's rare to see a game made by double fine with bland characters, obnoxious gameplay and boring story  however this game has all three. The combat system in this game is turn based with no strategy, that however I can stand I enjoy games like Final Fantasy or Pokemon, however Double Fine decided to "innovate" by mixing in Real Time Events which just completely ruined it for me. Similarly to Psychonauts and Brutal legend this game features collectibles, however unlike these 2 games - collectibles are not a side-quest but are the main quest of the game and you cannot proceed until you have searched every last corners for those collectibles. content:
4, 2014
												Here is another beauty that I got thanks to that Double Fine humble bundle. Every time I start thinking of going back to console gaming these bundles and steam sales just drag me right back in the glorious world of PC gaming and the silly and serious experiences it has to offer.Costume Quest is a game that I read and saw a decent amount of before I played it from the various videogame news sites that I follow. As a result I went into the game with a certain amount of expectations which were not entirely met if I am being honest.Costume Quest is a pretty mediocre game. Its definitely not bad, but its not that good either. If you are hoping to find a game that can be used as an eight to ten hour distraction then you should be fine getting Costume Quest. If you want something that is more than a distraction then you need to look elsewhere. Because while this game has a lot of charm, its very superficial in some major parts of its design leaving the experience of playing this game feeling boring and repetitive in more than one instance. This is something I feel pretty strongly about, to that point that I'm not looking forward to the sequel that Double Fine recently announced. Unless there are some major changes being made to the gameplay aspect of the game which I don't think is going to happen to be honest.If you feel like reading a more detailed review you can find it here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/06/costume-quest.html.

content:
r 29, 2015
												This is a game for kids, not kids-at-heart. I'm an adult, that likes Halloween. I like dressing up in costumes, and both handing out and having candy. I try to host a Halloween party every year.I got this game because I was hoping that there would be the same level of dialouge and characters as in Psychonauts. It's not.It's a very, very simplistic game, with choose a button and some QTE stuff. The costumes change things a bit, but anyone who has played any RPG type games at all can probably figure out the two damage dealers, one healer, or one tank, one damage, one healer, and not ever really need to switch costumes, besides to look at the different attacks.It's not a bad game for kids at all. The writing is still decent, and some of the jokes were amusing, but as an adult fan of Doublefine who purchased it for myself, I feel let down. It's also a very short game. Again, one that would more appeal to a kid audience.There IS a market for more adult-based Halloween costume style games out there that don't need horror or sex. I just wish Doublefine had realized that.

content:
y 15, 2015
												This game is all about the charm. The story isn't the same ol' derivative RPG story. The characters & setting are very enjoyable. I especially enjoyed playing this during Halloween, It put me in the holiday spirit.As an RPG there's nothing truely ground breaking here. The combat is ok, It's a class based system. Classes are selected through a series of costumes. Some costumes have healing abilities, some are damage/crowd control & others are defensive. It may sound unique & interesting, but the battles generally all go the same way due to the fact that your abilities are not able to be activated till the 3rd round. Damage for 3 rounds, if the enemy is still up, stun heal & damage battle over.I'm a fan of Tim Schafer's work, but I'm going to rate his work on it's own merits. This game is fun & charming & I would recommend it, but I would say wishlist it & wait for a sale.

This review explains how Double Fine's Costume Quest is a shallow, repetitive, featureless example of the RPG adventure game genre.[. . .] You do 1-3 identical attacks, then 1-3 identical dodges, and on every third turn special moves. That’s the only combat rhythm, and you’ll be doing it until every battle is a chore. There are no combos; no combat varieties; no difficult build decisions; no in-battle items; and, except for ‘go for the priest first,’ there is no strategy. content:
er 4, 2013
												Yeah, I'm really going to suffer through a bunch of idiotic tutorial dialogue one speech bubble at a time with no option to skip to the next line when I'm done reading. It's really good and well-thought-out that all the "important" conversations give me two options: 1) stare at text bubble long after im finished reading it or 2) skip entire conversation by pressing escape. I'm using sarcasm btw. I'm being sarcastic. I am utilizing a sarcastic tone to convey the opposite meaning of the literal definition of my words. In truth, the instant the last Steam Trading Card drops I'm going to be quitting and immediately deleting local content.If the dialogue was at-all interesting maybe it'd be worth sitting still through the horribly-paced cutscenes, but every conversation is Nick Jr. level garbage, dripping with that awful, condescending slime of Idiotic Childrens' Programming for Idiotic Children. It's patronizing, unimaginatively hokey, constantly condescending and utterly unbearable.It's also really insanely good that the unimportant "flavor" conversations CAN be skipped one bubble at a time, thus proving that the designers were capable of implementing this feature, but for whatever reason they then decided all the Extremely Important Cutscene Dialogue needed to be read at a speed of approximately one speech bubble every thirty seconds.Also the overworld control is pretty clunky (with a strange "momentum pause" when switching directions 90 degrees at a time) - probably feels a lot better on a controller, but WASD for life. Thankfully I'm probably not going to end up being horribly horribly frustrated by it because I don't plan on actually playing this game. The battles are moderately cool I guess if you're into Final Fantasy and/or QTE-styled fights (press key to select thing, press key when slider is in the sweet spot to do thing) and maybe the costume mechanics are good, maybe they're terrible, I'm unfortunately never going to find out because every two minutes I'm interrupted by a cutscene that I end up completely skipping once my patience runs out, so I end up further and further separated from the most "important" plot elements or story goals or whatever these cutscenes are intended to convey.In the interests of pointing out the positives: The graphics are very nice and colorful, and since there's no voice-acting there's no terrible voice-acting to either disable or bîtch about the inability to disable.Recommended for slow readers, fans of terrible cinematic pacing, and lobotomy patients.

content:
, 2016
												One of the better examples of why indy developers should be allowed to exist, unfortunately several flaws in this game prevent recommendation.Technically, the game has limited resolution modes and generally doesn't behave like a PC game.  Being unaware of foreground windowing prevents foreground switching and causes the game to crash... that's ok, developers probably weren't aware that DirectX 3.0 was introduced in 1997, so it's understandable they wouldn't have bothered to test the game under Windows. Artwork is 3D which at least beats going 2D platformer, but it's still extremely low effort.Gameplay quickly becomes stale and repetitive, which is the only chance the developers had in way of apology for their negligence on the artwork and on making the game compatible with Windows. Simply too hard to approve.

content:
4
												Wow.   Looked so great.  However, after playing for an hour I'm done.  To start with, the controls are counter-intuative and difficult to control.   They feel like they were ported from a game controller game.  Anyways, on a PC they don't work well.The plot is text based and the text bubbles move by -very- rapidly even for a fast reader..  Don't even try to read them outloud if playing in a group.    If you are distracted for a moment, you don't get to read what each character says.  Durning game play you must complete some tasks that require you to move accurately and quickly.  If you fail the task you start again.  Nothing spells "fun" like repeating a task that is only difficult because the controls are poor.In any event, after less than an hour's game play - this feels like a quick and dirty port of a console game with little testing for the PC market.  Shame, look fun, good concept, nice graphics.Horrible game play due to a quick, poorly done port.  Wish I could get my $10 back.

												costume quest is a pretty neat rpg done in the spirit of halloween. i must say this is a great rpg for gamers new and old. there is no item managing that hardcore rpg games have which means young and old both can enjoy this game without worry of having to run back to the store. there is a store in game though which has battle cards with varying effects u can use equip each charecter with 1 card swappable outside of battle.  healing wise there is none other then in battle so no worrys of dieing from being unprepared.one of the toughest parts about this game is prob the boss battles aside from that the trying to get every defense and attack perfect by pressing the right button. also to talk about the battles pretty simple just attack and defend before the enemy hits you u try to press the correct button if hit the correct one critical attack and in defense better defense or a dodge and if right card equiped counter. after 3 turns ur specials charged which they are pretty nice addition. but do not take the game lightly u can lose battles if ur not careful. but there is no such thing as gameover in this game it just places u in the area right before the battle <3also to note there is a varity of costumes which u have to find the parts to make them each comes with a special ablity which is pretty neat. oh and there is special ablitys for some of them useable in the field which adds to the fun.now if u like rpgs that arent that tough yet still fun give costume quest a go as its worth a play and i would say a replay <3   oh and did i mention candy? content:
20, 2014
												This game does some things wonderfully. It's a fantastic portrayal of the way a costume transforms you from a kid wearing a bucket or a cardboard box into a powerful figure who kicks ♥♥♥ and stands up for justice. The moment of suspense after you knock on the door when you don't know who or what is behind it is a really nice touch. The cel-shaded models in the battle scenes look great.But do be aware this is a very _simple_ game. It could be a good introduction to the CRPG genre for younger players, but there's not much depth to be found here. The story is charming but simple. There is some variety in the abilities you get with the costumes and accessories, but there's no skill progression to speak of, and each party member may only have a single accessory. The tactically-minded will find there's an accessory you can get mid-game that lets you cheese your way through fights for everything except bosses.So the thumbs-up here is a potential thumbs-up if you're looking for a game for your kids. If you're old enough to have your own Steam account, you've probably outgrown this.

												What an amazing game!  It might seem like this is just a simple kids game, but it is actually so much fun! er 2, 2011
												Costume Quest plays like an introductory JRPG: classes are mapped onto interchangeable costumes that are unlocked by finding materials in the environment, equipment comes in the form of 'battle stamps' that can be purchased from vendors, and there are no consumables or 'game over' moments. Combat is simple and turn-based, but made slightly more interesting by requiring the player to press a random button at a given time to maximize or mitigate damage.It's a Doublefine game, so humor is a big part of the presentation. It's suitable for younger players, though some of the jabs at consumer culture and common RPG schticks will probably go over their heads.Between CQ and its (included) DLC, there's roughly eight hours of content.

content:
er 13, 2013
												Costume Quest is the best holiday related game I have ever played. You play as a kid on Halloween trick or treating with you twin. Your twin gets kidnapped by monsters and you have to rescue her. Luckily your costume allows you to transform into a giant robot and allows you to take down your evil opponents. The combat is turn based RPG at its most basic yet most fun. You have a basic attack that crits if you perform varied quick time events and after three turns can use a super move that also varies. There are several costumes to collect and each one had different health, damage, and supers. The supers can be buffs, heals or damage. Using varied costumes is the key to success in Costume Quest and is some of the most fun. Throughout the game you will encounter new party members and can set their costume to your liking. There are also badges that you can equip to party members in order to give them passive or activated abilities. You buy these with candy which you can get by fighting monsters or trick or treating (duh). Overall the game looks great and controls just as well. The only complaint I have is the length which is about 4-5 hours but the DlC continues the story and extends the game by 2 hours. Get this game if you are even slightly curious about it. It has an old video game feel that you don’t find in games to much today.

content:
er 14, 2013
												This game will make you feel like a child again. You play as a child whose sibling, dressed as candy, is kidnapped by gremlins who steal candy on Halloween for their gremlin overlord. You collect a series of costumes and candy to work your way towards your kidnapped sibling. During a tedious RPG-style battle system, you become a Power Rangers-style gigantic form of your costume, each with a unique ability. Using the powers of your costumes, you defeat the gremlins, collect the candy in the area, and move on to the next. The humor is charming. There are many childlike jokes told as you communicate with other trick-or-treaters, but not in a sense of immaturity; the jokes will make you laugh like a child, fully encompassing the character. If you're a fan of the way Nintendo makes you feel when playing their games, or any of Double Fine's other imaginative productions, this game is a definite pick-up.

content:
, 2013
												A simple, yet very fun RPG made by Double Fine Productions. Not very surprising, since the company is known for making pretty fun games. Costume Quest uses a simple turn-based RPG battle system, so there isn't really any kind of learning curve to it. The story is pretty simple and not deep, but the characters are likeable. The costumes you wear decide what you fight as and what attack and special ability you have. It can be pretty fun to mess around and decide what the best team to use is. The game isn't really hard, but if you don't have a good team set up, it can be easy to lose. Even if you lose, there is no penalty or anything of that sort, which is sort of nice. If your a fan of simple turn-based RPGs, I fully recommend you try this game. (Note: If you aren't very good with quick time events using keyboard butons, I fully recommend you use a controller, preferably an Xbox 360 controller.)

												Great game if you have a little time on your hands.  It streamlines the RPG experience with a simpler exploration feel that keeps the user involved until the end. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
y 1, 2014
												Costume Quest is an RPG about trick-or-treating. You control a group of kids tasked with defeating a small army of monsters led by an evil witch in order to retrieve whichever of the sibling protagonists you don't choose at the start.Did I mention that it's by Double Fine Productions? Because that would explain that previous paragraph, for you.There's a weird division in imagination and reality in this game. The monsters are real. The plight is real. There's actually a witch ordering giant crows to steal candy to further her mysterious plans. But then once you enter battle, it becomes imaginary. I believe. I could certainly be wrong, but nobody else seems to notice when the heroes transform into colossal and more impressive versions of the things they're wearing costumes of. Even the monsters look much less doofy once battle commences. This all brings up an interesting point to consider, though, which is what the final boss looks like in reality - it's only ever seen in battle, you see (Grubbins on Ice notwithstanding, as that doesn't seem as married to this rule as the main game).Gameplay mostly consists of exploring, collecting, and fighting. You'll be searching every nook and cranny for various items to complete various quests, as well as to further the plot. Battles are launched by knocking on doors for candy (and later by encountering roaming monsters, as well), and abide by a turn-based system which encourages timed button presses, a la Mario RPG. There are also, notably, a limited number of battles (except maybe in the upper floors of the mall), so you're not expected to sit around and grind levels for hours to proceed.Different costumes give the kids different powers. Outside of battle, they're useful for overcoming obstacles or completing objectives. But inside battle, costumes are essentially classes. The robot is all attack, while the knight can defend himself or his teammates. Lady Liberty can heal the entire team partially, but the unicorn can heal one person to 100% HP.Movement is kind of odd, at first. If you point in a direction, your kid swivels in place to face that direction before setting off. Once in motion, you can make smooth turns, but pointing in the opposite direction will cause them to stop, turn, and then go. You get used to it by the second area, but it'll feel pretty wonky at first.The console releases of Costume Quest eventually received the paid DLC "Grubbins on Ice". You'll be pleased to hear that the DLC is now included at no additional charge! This bonus Winter-themed adventure sends the kids to the Grubbins' home... world? Dimension? Something. There are new costumes, stamps, and abilities to be found, and new monster types to fight. It's a quality addition, and worth the attention once the main game is complete.Costume Quest has become something of a Halloween tradition for me now. It's just short enough to invite such replayability. There are three major areas in the main game, and one more in Grubbins on Ice. Each one will likely take about two or three hours to complete, giving the game an 8-12 hour length for each playthrough. Just perfect for a run-through once every October, and the perfect game for the holiday. Costume Quest captures the spirit and imagination of trick-or-treating spendidly. Which suits me fine. I'm too old to go out trick or treating, anymore, but you're never too old to fight monsters in your underwear at 2 in the morning.

												Costume Quest plays like an introductory JRPG: classes are mapped onto interchangeable costumes that are unlocked by finding materials in the environment, equipment comes in the form of 'battle stamps' that can be purchased from vendors, and there are no consumables or 'game over' moments. Combat is simple and turn-based, but made slightly more interesting by requiring the player to press a random button at a given time to maximize or mitigate damage.It's a Doublefine game, so humor is a big part of the presentation. It's suitable for younger players, though some of the jabs at consumer culture and common RPG schticks will probably go over their heads.Between CQ and its (included) DLC, there's roughly eight hours of content.

												This is a really enjoyable RPG. Probably the only RPG in a while that i found fun to play. The basic story is you have monsters invade the kids town to collect candy which ends with you having to use different costumes for combat and exploration as well as collecting candy by trick or treating houses and by defeating monsters.  Only criticisms are thats it's a bit too easy and the combat which i liked at first for it's anime style gets boring after a while. Also the Grubbins On Ice DLC feels like a bit of a copy and paste of the original story with just a new setting and a few new costumes. 												i love the atmosphere of this game.  story telling is charming. i like the shell shaded art direction.   i love the dialogue sometimes, its so witty.  i love the world this game is placed in, its a short game, and i wish this game was longer.  on the other hand the game battle system is TOO repetitive.  VERY simple battle mechanics which is like a double edged sword. every battle in the game is very similar and it gets dull after awhile. dodging attacks is dead simple. as long as you get the timing right, that's all that matters. that is way too simple. but once you get the hang of the battle mechanics, the battles flow in and out of the world map very quickly which i likecontrols on the kb and mouse plain SUCKS, use an xbox controller.the last boss final phase is horribly over powered, they could have designed his moves better instead of a cheap "wipe out the whole team" move. with all that said, this game was still loads of fun you should chekc it out!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
20, 2014
												Costume Quest is a game that is both a lot of fun and incredibly gripping. This is the kind of game that wisks you away back to your childhood memories of roaming the neighborhood going door to door trick-or-treating and the whole adventure feels like the kind of 'adventures' I went on as a kid. The gameplay itself was also pretty interesting, despite most of it being completing quests and turn based battles. The ability to construct new costumes and gain different abilities in the overworld and the battle system was great. Plus I feel that some of the quest objective help reinforce the Halloween theme, as each part of the world has trick-or-treating at every house in the area, much how as a kid I made sure to hit up every house. My only real complaint is that the battle system can get a bit repetitive and it feels just a bit to easy to do well with, but other than that I had a great time playing Costume Quest. It took me a little over 5 hours to play through the main story, but I still have yet to play the "Grubbins on Ice" story, so I would have to say that this is one of the few games where I feel it is still worth it if you pay the full $10 for it.

ber 20, 2014
												The mechanics are stellar, this game is practically perfect.I finished the entire game and got all the achievements but I'm so addicted I still crave for it. I can't wait for Costume Quest 2!This game hooks you up right from the start, as you get more costumes and battlestamps the possibilities gets much deeper.For example, my favorite combination was the Statue of Liberty with splash damage, Vampire with additional damage and the Unicorn with health regen. You can heal the entire party with Lady Liberty and same for the Vampire but it's also a life steal. Then if either of them dies, the Unicorn can revive them. The Unicorn has high health and with the health regen, it is basically invincible.

content:
15, 2013
												Well Double Fine you made another good game, I applaude you. See Double Fine continues to make good games, something few companies can do, much like RareWare in the 1990's, Tim Schafer's Double Fine seems to be dishing out game after game of quality. He is of course well known to the people who have heard of him, but that is shockingly few people. His games like Grim Fandango, and Phychonauts are glimmering underappreciated diamonds, and his lastest game Costume Quest does nothing to tarnish that reputation.Now why do I compare Double Fine to Rare? Easy, they both made a multitude of games that made them very popular, Double Fines biggest issue is it is still the unknown company, thier games come out, they look cool to some people, I play them, love them, then I tell other people how good they are for just being 20 bucks or less, then no one plays them. But I hold no resentment towards those people because I grew up with with Tim at my side, a man that made good games, I do hope that someday I can say 'Hey, you know that game that everyone likes that just came out, try this it's made by the same guys.' Then we get people playing Double Fines old catalog of games.But about Costume Quest, it's good, it's charming, it has a few pop culture references, most don't seem out of place unless you know them. But the big thing is, it shows that Double Fine can make a decent Role Playing Game. Now don't get me wrong it's not as in depth as some major RPG's, but it does what you want it to do. There are no voices, just text, which is fine, the dialouge makes me chuckle, and brings out the little things in characters. It's just enough exploration, it is a little limiting, but it cuts down on annoying long term searches, and overall the game keeps at a fairly difficult stance. See it's these types of games that I like to see game companies make, they normally make puzzle games or platformers, but then they release an explore centered RPG and then it's actually good. That is what I like to see, I like to see companies improve and expand thier game base with more than platformers, because really I will lose intrest eventually, but it is safe to say Double Fine is keeping another fan interested and excited for the future.

												Costume Quest did a great job of scratching my Final Fantasy itch without requiring the hundreds of hours your average FF game requires. The combat can be a bit repetitive, and the skill level is defnitely geared toward more novice players, but the game is short enough neither of these stuck around long enough to bother me. As one would expect from Double Fine, the art direction is fantastic, and the Creepy Treats cards are a great blend of Garbage Pail Kids-style art and trading cards with some of the best puns and just weird candies you can imagine. As a short treat or break from the norm, Costume Quest is sure to satisfy.

												   One word to sum it up? Charming.   Costume quest is a turn-based RTS at heart and enjoyable from start to end. I honestly can't think of any con except maybe the low difficulty.   Costume Quest comes with achievements, collectibles, spells, monsters,costumes, bosses. What else does a game need in the end?   Also comes with a free DLC and the promise for more and while not trying to spoil the end, it does offer an opening for future development.   My advice, get it, buy it, play it. You won't regret it. Worth every penny.

												Costume Quest is incredibly adorable. Although it took an extra year to get it from the consoles to the PC, I don't think anything was lost in the transition. Heck, it comes with the DLC, too!Gameplay's kind of a little repetative; you trick or treat, you kill some Gomoblins, do some puzzlin' here and there, sometimes there's a boss fight. There isn't much to break up the formula, but it works well enough on its own.What stood out to me was how charming the game itself is. It's very much a trip back to childhood, with memories of homemade box robots or giant-headed felt unicorns. It's really cute and to me one of it's big selling points.If you have any sort of childhood nostalgia, this will be a game for you.

												Short answer, yes, i higly recommend it.And the long one:Costume Quest is a light-hearted rpg game, made by one of my favorites developers, Double Fine. The game mechanics are really nice, there are a great variety of costumes and somewhat variable enemies. My only complaint regarding the gameplay is that the fighting mechanics get a little bit repetitive due to some unskipable animations, but nothing too big. Some peaple reported some bugs, but i haven't found any in my playtrough. The game story is light-hearted, but good and there are some really nice jokes. The game's graphics are a cartoonish style and are really well polished and beautifull. I really loved the game, it's a really escape from the same repetitive game formula of nower days, It is somewhat short, I took about 5 hours to finish it, and i'm usually slower than the average to beat a game (It took me about 4 hours to beat the DLC grubbings ice). That being said, I highly recommend Costume Quest for all players.9.8/10

												A mediocre RPG propped up by the considerable charm of the writers of Double Fine Productions. Combat is often agonizingly boring, with almost no options but requiring timed button presses that doesn't let you just blur it all out like you would Final Fantasy or Pokemon battles. Still, the game is adorable and features wonderfully written dialogue all the way down to the NPCs, making you want to explore the world and all of it's crannys, even if the battles frequently make you want to put it down. Hopefully some depth will be added to the upcoming sequel, but until then this is a cute, if slight, addition to the rich Double Fine canon.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
r 28, 2016
												"Costume Quest" is a fine opportunity to get into the Halloween mood. Or even deeper.It is a one-player RPG game involving two twin siblings getting separated by candy-greedy monsters from Repugia and two friends of theirs. So one sibling gets kidnapped and the other three children (including you as the twin brother or sister) set off for the rescue while fighting monsters, bosses and having fun by collecting Halloween stuff (costumes, candy, candy cards, battle stamps) and solving quests that get in your way.The gameplay: Most of the time you will walk around places like your hometown or the town's mall and search for items and quests. All of these help you progress in the story and getting stronger. One quest you must complete a couple of times in order to progress is to knock on every available door to ask for treats. Either you just get them or have to battle a monster (that has occupied this house). So the other part of the game are the battles. The children use their costumes they've achieved (pumpkin, black cat, vampire, statue of liberty, etc...) and their special powers to fight the different monsters. And because it's an RPG you wait for your characters' turns and choose the actions they're suppoused to do now while the monsters get their turns, too. You can loose battles but never die. You just would have to try again. Every win is rewarded with experience points, candy and other items.During all this you have your note book with you in which you have an overlook of your status, quests (and their status), costumes (with description), candy cards and a variety of battle stamps which can be used for battle by your characters.I found "Costume Quest" very playable, the controls are easy to learn (and they're changeable if you really can't operate with them). I played with the keyboard and it worked just fine. It's a fun RPG with a good mixture of exploring, collecting and fighting. It's also easy to play, so also RPG beginners shouldn't have trouble to finish this game sooner or later.The cartoonish 2.5/3D graphics are mostly sweet and lovely designed, that goes especially for the settings you go to.  They're colourful but not rainbow puking bright, they mostly match the Halloween season. When it goes to the characters, I find the children, their battle characters and the monsters were designed okay. I can't say that about the adult characters who either look like obese puppets, lifeless big-nosed humans or stick figures with grotesque heads and faces. They don't only look strange but also quite lifeless. I wished that a bit more effort would have went into their designs. But to the game's credit: the adults play a very minor role compared to the children.The sound is so-so: I enjoyed the musical score very much. But the sound? It completely containts sound effects (which are fine), no voices (outside the occesional grunts of monster characters and human background mumbling in more crowded places). This means that the dialogues are all text bubbles and there are even no simple sounds expressed by the characters, wether a "Gasp!" or "Huh?" or "Ouch" or something. I find this negative since at least a bit of voice acting brings extra life to these characters but here, everybody is totally quiet. What about extras? There are achievements, trading cards, one minigame about apple bobbing and there is also an additional chapter included called "Grubbins on Ice" that goes on right after the story of the main game. I can't say it's that exciting or so much fun, you practically do the same things and collect new costumes but without Halloween going on. Still, it's worth for a bit of fun and the achievements.So, can I recommend "Costume Quest"? Yes, absolutely. It's a sweet, fun game all around Halloween and the fantasy of children celebrating it. If you can't stand Halloween or just don't care about it, then I guess this shouldn't stop you from trying but you might have less joy with that game.And if you're into RPGs or starting this, you definitely should check it out.

												I remember getting this for the PS3 on the PSN monthly giveaway.  The French Fry costume bug was an issue on there, which prevented me from being able to finish it.  However, I picked this back up on a sale and haven been going through it a second time (and now getting past where I could not!) and have enjoyed it, A LOT.  Good humor and the combat is fun.  Keep in mind this is a light-hearted take on an RPG.  So much so that my 4 year old plays it on his own (and does well, I might add) and it one of his favorite games.  If you are expecting some deep tactical turn-based combat, then you may want to look else where.  But, if you want a fun little game that has a cute story and is great to kick up your feet and get lost in for a little bit, I highly recommend it.Pros:- Cute story- Good humor (for me, at least)- Fun exploring areasCons:- Not very deep tactical combat system- Battles can be repetitive towards the end of the gameDon't let the cons scare you though.  I have enjoyed playing through this game (twice now!)

content:
r 11, 2015
												My inner child identifies with this game on a spiritual level. Costume Quest is a casual, adventure RPG from Double Fine Productions (a group of people who have yet to let me down with anything of theirs that I’ve played). Let’s get rocking.The GoodI could go on and on about the things that Costume Quest gets right, but I’ll try to keep it brief.The art is outstanding. While you are adventuring, everything appears (mostly) normal aside from the magical quality that Halloween lends to everything. However, when you are in combat, everything is suddenly crazy awesome. Your character’s get huge (as do the enemies), your costumes take on a life of their own, and it all looks great.There aren’t additional weapons or anything to pick up in CQ. Instead you find different costumes, each with it’s own set of attacks/abilities. I absolutely loved this aspect of the game.The story is simple, but entertaining and the characters are all quite likable.The environments really bring back that magical feeling that you got as as a child when Halloween was nigh. The nostalgia train is coming for you if you play this one.The BadThe game was too short. I wanted it to go on for many, many moons.The MehI’ve got nothing here.Verdict: YeaEspecially with Halloween upon us, Costume Quest is a must have for any collection. It’s fun, simple, and it will earn a special place in your heart (at least for those of you who love Halloween). You can find it in the Steam Store and, with the Halloween Sale coming up, I’m pretty sure it’ll be on sale sometime this month. As always, thanks for reading.

content:
r 31, 2015
												Costume Quest is one of those rare games that you get out of a $1 bundle and just kind of forget about. It's one of those surprise delights that you didn't know you had in your library. Such is Double Fine's track record with game's. But it's Halloween and nothing gets you in the mood for Halloween better then some good ole fashioned trick or treating.Costume Quest is very under-rated in my opinion. At first glance it's a childrens game. A simple, brainless game created for the young one's. That's where you're missing out. The game is incredibly fun. You get to go door to door trick-or-treating, collect candy, collect costumes and it doesn't matter what costume you wear, it's up to you! You want to be a pirate? Sure! You want to be a ninja? Why not? Throw in the statue of liberty and you got yourself a team! All while completing quests, collecting cards and finding yourself oddly intrigued in a somewhat predictable story. If you like games like South Park: The Stick of Truth and don't mind a much more toned down sense of humor, give this game a try. You won't regret it.

												If you've ever wanted a game that's almost exactly like Paper Mario, only themed around Halloween instead of the Mushroom Kingdom, you're in luck.  The gameplay is nearly identical in most respects (run around completing simple tasks, gain stamps/costumes/badges/levels to improve your characters, start combat with monsters by whacking them on the main screen, then go into turn-based battles with timed attack/defense commands), but it's fun and light-hearted, not too difficult, and has a good sense of humor, i.e. Double Fine Halloween Paper Mario.  Play it with a controller, or you'll be sad.  And not that the art style doesn't look good already, but if your video card can handle it, enable the "secret" command-line SSAA mode (-ssaa2x or -ssaa4x) and it looks fantastic.

content:
er 27, 2011
												Costume Quest is incredibly adorable. Although it took an extra year to get it from the consoles to the PC, I don't think anything was lost in the transition. Heck, it comes with the DLC, too!Gameplay's kind of a little repetative; you trick or treat, you kill some Gomoblins, do some puzzlin' here and there, sometimes there's a boss fight. There isn't much to break up the formula, but it works well enough on its own.What stood out to me was how charming the game itself is. It's very much a trip back to childhood, with memories of homemade box robots or giant-headed felt unicorns. It's really cute and to me one of it's big selling points.If you have any sort of childhood nostalgia, this will be a game for you.

content:
9, 2015
												This game is very simple, and in some ways feels like a cheaper, off-brand version of a bigger JRPG, namely one of the Persona series, given that you fight with the powers of a swappable costume.But it's got a lot of charm, delightfully cohesive theming, good writing that allows the kids to be kids, and sprawling level design with slightly retro area access puzzles that fit into the Hallowe'en theme very well.There are turn-based battles with quick time events to maximize your damage and reduce the enemies'. They aren't always easy. There is also a two layered strategic system of costume specific special abilities and 'battle stamp' special abilities that can be used with any costume. There are quite a lot of ways to build effective combinations, and in some difficult battles, you will have to adapt your strategy to the circumstances to succeed.Downsides? Well, the camera angle is fixed and with levels so sprawling and complex, it can be easy to miss things hidden behind the foreground that are mandatory for story progression and to have to search for them.Some of the puzzle solving is quite silly, and the player characters' unprompted hints to solve them can be annoying as often as they are helpful.If a baddie wandering on the overworld map initiates combat with you and you lose, you get spat back out in exactly the same place, and the baddie will immediately initiate combat again, giving you no time to switch up your strategy before being launched into exactly the same battle; that can be a bit frustrating.And finally, the lack of complexity can mean that the simple mechanics get a little bit dull even over the short playtime.So its JRPG lite, but I recommend it for the charm alone. This game has actually made me question my disillusionment with the corporatization of Hallowe'en by showing me the cuter costumes and candy in a more wholesome and fun light. If you have kids, invite them to play it too. It seems like a very child-friendly game.

And I liked it.You play Wren, a new kid who on Halloween night loses her brother Reynold to some monsters that think he's literally a piece of candy. The world of costume quest is rather open as you navigate the town, collecting candy and fight monsters. The combat is turn based where you go from the semi isometric view to a combat zone and whatever costume you're wearing, well, you're now some superhero or creepy monster yourself. It was pretty cool. Throughout the course of the game, you meet other kids from the neighborhood in town, at the mall, at a carnival, and whereever you go in between. Some of the kids will tag along and eventually, you'll have a team of three kids to take on the monsters.I could go on about the graphics and audio design, but they're nothing amazing so I'm just gonna conclude here.7.5/10

												This game is short and simplistic. The RPG combat is kinda like Paper Mario, in that you do QTEs to deal more damage. However, you usually only have the option to do a basic attack until your special is charged up (always after 3 turns) or you have a special stamp equipped. There are about ten costumes in both the normal game and the DLC, and only about half of them are worth using in combat compared to the others.Outside of combat, there are four enviroments to explore and solve puzzles in using costume abilities. You can hit basically anyone and anything with your candy pail, which is amusing. The dialogue isn't laugh out loud funny, but I smiled from time to time.The game really shines graphically. The characters are cute, the environments are given a lot of detail, and the battles look amazing. It's all very colorful. Music is average, however.All in all, playing this game is like playing a cartoon from Cartoon Network long ago. Worth buying if it's on sale.

content:
ber 25, 2015
												Usually when you think of a Halloween game, you think of a scary game, and those are all well and good; but what about a game that really brings the magic of Halloween itself? You know, costumes, trick or treating, having fun with your friends? Costume Quest somehow does it and does it very well. The first level already brims with nostalgia of days gone by (for me anyway) of walking the neighborhood at night and going door to door with a pale for the candy. You may wonder what the gameplay is like - well, first off the story is not serious, it's a light-hearted romp that'll make you smile for all ages. The overall story begins as your brother or sister (depending on who you choose to play as) gets kidnapped by strange monsters who love candy, and you are going to rescue them. The gameplay itself mostly is you going door to door in various places, and sometimes you get an adult with candy (which is like a currency in the game), or it could be a monster, which whom you have to fight.The fighting is done like a turn-based RPG, and you can get little things to help you out, called Battle Stamps. Each stamp has a unique ability you can use, each of your character gets one stamp per person, but you can switch them out if you don't care for it.There's no real dying in the game, you lose a battle, and you can just try again. The settings are really fun, like a neighborhood with various decorations, or a mall etc. The humor is really good, and adults and children will enjoy it, it's really a game for the family. Sadly, there's no co-op but it's fun on its own.There's also the DLC "Grubbins on Ice" included which adds 1-2 hours more. The core game isn't TOO long even getting everything, maybe 4-5 hours? But it's a lot of fun, and if you want to feel that Halloween nostalgia, this is the perfect game for you! The sequel is also very good, and worth checking out if you like the first one.

content:
2015
												Costume Quest is a game about capitalism and the futility of fighting the system. You play as Wren or Reynold, fraternal twins locked into a system in which happiness is always kept at arm's length. Your twin, the object of your worldly fulfillment, is taken from you, and you are forced to incorporate yourself into the capitalist consumer machine in order to free them from bondage - i.e. willfully enslaving yourself even deeper in order to cast off perceived oppression. The erstwhile heroes are indoctrinated into consumerism through perceived need. Costumes and battle stamps are tools by which they can defeat their perceived oppressors, and candy and creepy treats are the currency by which they can obtain them. The creepy treats only award a special costume upon completing a full set, forcing the consumer-hero to seek out other members of their in-group to trade with and developing a reliance upon victimizing the out-group in order to obtain more. The same is true for candy, but on a much larger scale: widescale destruction and abuse of natural resources is encouraged, and upon reentering a zone the supply magically replenishes itself. Candy is ultimately spent on battle stamps, an entirely extraneous commodity that the game can be won without, but is marketed as invaluable and a means by which to constantly sink the children's personal supply of wealth.The true capitalist hero of this story is Sadie, a brave young entrepeneur with a monopoly on the battle stamps market who is happy to aid the heroes in their fight against the villainous 'monsters.' She allows her customers to develop a dependence upon her product before beginning to dramatically ramp up the price to obtain newer and better versions of the same - designed obselescence at its finest. By the end of the game the player is lucky if they have several hundred pieces of candy in their bucket, while Sadie sits on thousands that the player spent to constantly upgrade their battle stamps. The 'monsters' of the game are cast as villains bent on hoarding all the world's candy for themselves, when in reality they are collecting it in order to save their own lives. Sadie, on the other hand, is motivated purely by profit - lying, expanding, and price-gouging to drive it ever higher.The harsh reality is that this game is designed to indoctrinate the player into heedlessly reaping the world's resources and victimizing their competition in the name of achieving fulfillment. They are taught to at the same time fear and trust the two heads of the capitalist serpent, sybomically mirrored by the twin heads of the Doublefine logo: the Repugians, who are the face of foreign investments, and Sadie, the friendly face who is always there to help. 10/10 illuminati confirmed.

er 2, 2011
												Costume Quest plays like an introductory JRPG: classes are mapped onto interchangeable costumes that are unlocked by finding materials in the environment, equipment comes in the form of 'battle stamps' that can be purchased from vendors, and there are no consumables or 'game over' moments. Combat is simple and turn-based, but made slightly more interesting by requiring the player to press a random button at a given time to maximize or mitigate damage.It's a Doublefine game, so humor is a big part of the presentation. It's suitable for younger players, though some of the jabs at consumer culture and common RPG schticks will probably go over their heads.Between CQ and its (included) DLC, there's roughly eight hours of content.

content:
er 8, 2015
												Costume quest is a small, but fun game about saving your sibling after he/she is kidnapped by monsters who are trying to steal all of the candy. The objective of the game is to go to each area, collect candy as well as costumes (hence the name costume quest) and fight any monsters that cross your path.The game style is turn based combat with each costume giving you a different ability, and different quicktime event-like buttons to press to do more damage. The one little problem I have with the game is the fact that the (spoiler alert) French Fry and Vampire costume quicktime event/button press can prompt you to mash the shift key. On Windows, this is a little bit of a nuisance, as the game will minimize and ask if you want to turn sticky keys on. It isn't that big of a deal however, due to the fact that it's a turn based game.The game is not too much of a challenge if you can find the right combinations of costumes and battle stamps with which to fight the enemies. One can easily finish all of the quests simply by playing the game and not going too far out of the way to complete objectives.The characters are lovable (even the grubbins), the style is pretty cool, and the story, while not too exciting, is fun.I would reccomend trying it out.

content:
ry 14, 2014
												Short answer, yes, i higly recommend it.And the long one:Costume Quest is a light-hearted rpg game, made by one of my favorites developers, Double Fine. The game mechanics are really nice, there are a great variety of costumes and somewhat variable enemies. My only complaint regarding the gameplay is that the fighting mechanics get a little bit repetitive due to some unskipable animations, but nothing too big. Some peaple reported some bugs, but i haven't found any in my playtrough. The game story is light-hearted, but good and there are some really nice jokes. The game's graphics are a cartoonish style and are really well polished and beautifull. I really loved the game, it's a really escape from the same repetitive game formula of nower days, It is somewhat short, I took about 5 hours to finish it, and i'm usually slower than the average to beat a game (It took me about 4 hours to beat the DLC grubbings ice). That being said, I highly recommend Costume Quest for all players.9.8/10
